Aspergillus belongs to Aspergillaceae and is widely distributed in nature. Although it causes food spoilage and is extremely toxic, it has a key role in food fermentation. Aspergillus also has a positive contribution to antibacterial effects
126 . Trichoderma belongs to Hypocreaceae and is mainly distributed in rot, seeds, plant residues, organic fertilisers, soil, and air. Trichoderma has good medicinal value. For example, it can be used to produce cellulase
127 , producing antibiotics, and so on
128 . Living on saprophytic life, Penicillium sp. can cause food to rot, but it also has certain antibacterial and anti-inflammatory effects.
